iati-activity.title: Aceh Programme implementation
iati-activity.description:
This particular output spells out management related aspects of the project including steering committee, project board, monitoring and evaluation, project assurance as well as mid-term review and reporting.
The Aceh Government Transformation Programme (AGTP) addresses the urgent need to strengthen the capacity of Aceh's provincial government and ensure that it has the wherewithal to efficiently assume the responsibilities, functions, resources and assets it will inherit from the Aceh and Nias Reconstruction and Rehabilitation Body (BRR) in 2009.
The project will help ensure a systematic and smooth transition from BRR to provincial and local governments that will safeguard the still fragile legacy of the billions of dollars invested by donors and the Government into rebuilding the province after the devastating tsunami and 30 years of conflict. Currently, there is neither the technical capacity nor the budget allocation at the provincial level to carry out theses important tasks.

iati-activity.title: Arafura and Timor Seas Ecosystem Action Programme
iati-activity.description: Arafura and Timor Seas Ecosystem Action Programme (ATSEA)

iati-activity.title: Arafura & Timor Seas Ecosystem
iati-activity.description:
The project is designed to ensure an integrated, cooperative, sustainable, ecosystem based management and use of the living coastal and marine resources of the Arafura and Timor Seas, through the formulation, inter-governmental adoption and initial implementation of a Regional Strategic Action Plan (SAP) and National Action Plans (NAPs). Through the GEF intervention, including the undertaking of a Trans-Boundary Diagnostic Analysis (TDA), development of a Strategic Action Programme (SAP), and implementation of innovative demonstration projects, the littoral nations will be greatly assisted to collaboratively understand and address the shared waters problems that cannot be solved by any one country on its own. Indonesia and Timor Leste are the two directly benefiting countries, recipients to the GEF fund, while Australia supports the initiative as active partner and provision of in-kind contribution. The project outputs are: (1) Development of Trans-boundary Diagnostic Analysis (TDA) which identifies the ATS trans-boundary priority environmental problems, environmental & socio-economic impacts, sectoral and root causes and governance analyses; (2) SAP and NAP Development; (3) SAP and NAP initial implementation; and (4) development of regional cooperation mechanism.
(1) Transboundary Diagnostic Analysis (TDA) document which identifies the ATS transboundary priority environmental problems, environmental & socio-economic impacts, sectoral and root causes and governance analyses; (2) Strategic Action Program (SAP) for ATS region and National Action Programs (NAPs) for each ATS littoral nation; (3) Demonstration Projects identified in SAP and NAPs established and completed; (4) Regional cooperation mechanism developed and approved, simultaneously strengthening ATSEF and Regional self-financing mechanism, such as a multi-lateral trust fund or partnership council to ensure the implementation of the SAP, developed.

iati-activity.title: Development Advisory Services
iati-activity.description: Development Advisory Services. Support to Country Office

iati-activity.title: Development Advisory Services
iati-activity.description:
Indonesia's emergence as a lower Middle Income Country has altered the development cooperation context. As such, the development context in Indonesia is not static. In order to remain relevant it is vital for UNDP, as for any development agency, to avoid restricting itself or being prone to inertia in relation to the development of new initiatives. Based on this clear need, this project will provide a resource through which UNDP and its partners in Indonesia can respond quickly to new situations and openings within the national policy framework and assist Indonesia in reaping the maximum benefit from ongoing and future initiatives.
This project aims to provide UNDP with the mechanism to support programme development, policy dialogue and UN Country Team activities, in particular:
Support high priority frameworks, or initiatives therein, such as Country Programmes, SRFs, UNDAFs, pursuance of MDGs and Joint Programmes
Enhance the consultative process between UNDP, Governments and donors, especially with respect to the realignment and programming of core and non-core resources.
Outputs:
knowledge-based advisory and programme services
coordination support in priority policy and institutional matters falling within UNDP practice areas

result.title: National and local institutions have the capacities to reduce the impact of disasters, especially climate change related disasters, on vulnerable communities
result.description: DRR-A has made significant contributions towards the formulation and establishment of regulatory instruments and institutional arrangements for implementing disaster risk reduction in Aceh. The project has also implemented Community Based Disaster Risk Reduction (CBDRR) program in 10 villages located in 10 districts. DRR-A has also improved to a significant degree the capacity of the Tsunami Disaster Mitigation Research Centre (TDMRC) to provide science-based products and services. The project has also contributed towards the establishment of a master's degree program in Disaster Management at the Universitas Syiah Kuala or Syiah Kuala University (Unsyiah.) Public awareness of disaster risk reduction was raised by DRR-A with campaigns using a wide range media, and the integration of disaster risk reduction knowledge into elementary, junior and high schools as well as the Modern Dayah curriculum. iati-activity.title: Energy Standard and Labeling
iati-activity.description: BARRIER REMOVAL TO THE COST-EFFECTIVE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF ENERGY EFFICIENCY STANDARDS AND LABELING PROJECT (BRESL)

document-link.title: Support to Indonesia's Energy Efficiency Testing and Certification Facilities and Expertise-JPF Approval letter

iati-activity.title: Energy Standard and Labeling
iati-activity.description:
BRESL will facilitate the transformation of the manufacture and sale of energy-efficient appliances and equipment through: 1) A regional initiative in Asia, with provision for general information, tools and training to all interested developing countries in the region plus customized efforts, all with a focus on regional cooperation; and, 2) National technical assistance to 5 developing countries in Asia. The project will focus largely on capacity building and assisting government, manufacturing, distributing, retail, consumer and environmental stakeholders throughout the Asian region to implement the most cost-effective energy efficiency measure available. In each participating country, priority activities will be carried out to help foster each country's preferred process for developing or expanding its ES&L program.
Component 1: Legal and regulatory basis for removing lowest EE technologies from the market and promoting high-efficiency technologies established.
Component 2: Institutional and individual capacity to secure on-the-ground implementation of regulatory frameworks, as well as actual standards and labeling programs developed.
Component 3: Information and technical assistance to manufacturers of covered products provided.
Component 4: Regional cooperation and information sharing functional.
Component 5: Pilot project set up demonstrating various aspects of the development and implementation of ES&L programs.

iati-activity.title: Indonesia Climate Change Trust Fund
iati-activity.description: Preparatory Arrangements for the Indonesia Climate Change Trust Fund (PREP-ICCTF)

iati-activity.title: Preparatory Indonesia Climate
iati-activity.description:
UNDAF Outcome(s) : Increased opportunities for sustainable livelihoods by 2010 improved environmental living conditions
CPAP Expected Output(s) : Capacity of Government, private sector and civil society to adhere to the international environmental agreements increased.
Descriptions : The Government of Indonesia established the Indonesia Climate Change Trust Fund (ICTTF) decree in September 2009. The ICCTF shall be nationally managed, and is part of government commitment to implement the Jakarta Commitment's to enhance national ownership and improve aid coordination in response to climate change. In this framework, the Government and the UNDP shall jointly establish and implement the project titled "Preparatory Arrangements for the Indonesia Climate Change Trust Fund (PREP-ICCTF)". Under term of signed Letter of Agreement (September 2009), the objects of the project shall be to (1) Provide support to priority climate change initiatives as prioritized by the Government, during an interim period, while the ICCTF is being established; (2) Provide Support and development and establishment of the ICCTF; and (3)support capacity development needs of the Government of Indonesia for the efficient and effective implementation of the ICCTF. The project shall enable the Government and national trustee to gradually assume full operational responsibility within the 18 month interim period.
The initial USD 50,000 TRAC budget is intended for preparatory activities, before the full funding from DFID and other donors is received. The key objectives of the project shall be to (1) Provide support to priority climate change initiatives as prioritized by the Government, during an interim period, while teh ICCTF is being established; (2) provide support and development for establishment of the ICCTF; (3) support capacity development needs of teh Government of Indonesia for the efficient and effective implementation of teh ICCTF.

iati-activity.title: Microturbine Cogeneration Technology Application Project
iati-activity.description: Microturbine Cogeneration Technology Application Project

iati-activity.title: Microturbine Co-Generation
iati-activity.description: This project will introduce, promote, demonstrate and facilitate the marketing and application of Microturbine Co-generation Technology (MCT) through six key components: (a) Technology Assessment and MCT Application Development; (b) Demonstrations & Market Development; (c) Technical Support for MCT Financing; (d) Policy & Institutional Support; (e) MCT Promotion Activities; and, (f) Technical Support for Local MCT Industry. From these 6 components, the following are the expected outcomes: (a) Enhanced knowledge of potential MCT applications; system benefits, availability and cost, as well as capacity and capability of local service providers for MCT systems; (b) Increased MCT applications in ICE sectors as well as market share of MCT, with resulting in GHG emission reduction, and reduction in MCT cost by about 25% average; c) Increased investments on MCT: banks/financing institutions providing loans for MCT projects; (d) Approval and implementation of policies supportive of MCT projects; e) Enhanced awareness of the benefits of MCT in order to increase the number of MCT users and planned MCT projects; and, f) Availability of locally made, and enhanced local manufacturing capability of MCT system components.

iati-activity.title: National Biodiv Planning to Support Impl CBD
iati-activity.description: Natiional Biodiversity Planning to Support the Implementation of the CBD 2011-2020 Strategic Plan in Indonesia.

iati-activity.title: National Biodiv Plan
iati-activity.description: Indonesia has developed the Indonesia Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan (IBSAP) in 2003. However, the country is facing a number of barriers to effective implementation of the IBSAP, including a lack of monitoring and evaluation mechanisms, limited resources, lack of awareness on the part of decision makers, and a lack of synergies among relevant institutions. The project objective is to strengthen National biodiversity framework for implementation of Indonesia Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan (IBSAP) and integration of Indonesia's obligations under the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) into its national development and sectoral planning frameworks in line with the CBD's Strategic Plan for 2011-2020. It will achieve this through a) creating synergies among all relevant stakeholders through the formation of a multi-sectoral advisory group on IBSAP; b) establishing awareness of the value of biodiversity and its role as both an economic engine as well as a major element powering climate resilience and adaptation; c) ensuring the institutional framework required for IBSAP is implemented and widely adopted throughout society. The the Ministry of Environment (MoE) is Implementing Partner of the project. UNDP on the request of the MoE will recruit consultants, procure of goods and services. The MoE in cooperation with BAPPENAS and LIPI will share responsibility to lead implementation of project activities and achievement of all project outputs.

iati-activity.title: Peace Through Development
iati-activity.description: Peace Through Development (PTD) : Provide a framework for UNDP's continued response to post conflct needs in the provices of North Maluku, Maluku and Central Sulawesi.

iati-activity.title: Peace Through Development
iati-activity.description: All three provinces have experienced major inter-group conflict since 1999. PTD is a five year programme commencing in 2005 that aims for enhanced capacity of government and civil society to formulate and implement policies and programmes on crisis sensitive development. Focusing primarily on selected districts and municipalities in the three provinces it focuses on two main areas of capacity development: 1) strengthened governance capacity to support long-term conflict prevention and peace building; and 2) social integration and peace-building promoted through sustainable solutions for displaced and returnee communities and improved livelihood opportunities.

iati-activity.title: Formulation MDGs-based plans
iati-activity.description:
OUTPUT 1: MDGs-based plans and budgets are formulated with active public participation of development partners and men and women equally
Indicators:
(i) Extent to which Papua Development Report, Papua Human Development Report and the Papua MDG Report are used for guiding pro-poor and MDG oriented policy formulation
(ii) Extent to which pro-poor and MDG database systems and POVERTY MAPS are working, accessible and used for policy formulation
(iii) Percentage of districts that use MDG/HD data in planning and budgeting systems and formulas
(iv) Percentage increase in provincial and district budget allocations for poverty reduction and MDG achievement
Baselines:
(i) The Papua Development and MDG Report have been drafted but not yet finalized
(ii) Lack of available and disaggregated pro-poor and MDG database to guide policy formulation
(iii) Less than 30 percent of districts use MDG/HD data in planning and budgeting systems and formulas
(iv) Less than 30percent of provincial and district budgets are allocated for poverty reduction and MDG achievement

iati-activity.description:
OUTPUT 2 : Local Government and civil society have basic systems and procedures for the delivery of gender sensitive, enhanced, sustainable and integrated basic services in health and education, particularly in rural and remote areas
Indicators:
(i) Availability and implementation of basic system and procedures. for the delivery of gender sensitive, enhanced, sustainable and integrated basic services in health and education, particularly in rural and remote areas

iati-activity.title: Sustainable livelihood
iati-activity.description:

Indicators:
(i) Percentage increase in income of target beneficiary households including women-headed household

Baseline:

(ii) Existing business
(iii) Existing growth in commercial lending
(iv) Non-existence of Business Development Centres
(v) Limited progress on legal formulation, spatial planning and land planning

- Participatory surveys / Focus Group Discussions (FGD) with government / non-government stakeholders on institutional, organizational, networking dimensions of provincial government.

iati-activity.title: Strengthening Community Based Forest and Watershed
iati-activity.description: Strengthening Community Based Forest and Watershed Management. (SCBFWM) Objective: To support efforts on reducing forest and land degradation in order to restore watershed functions and ecosystem services

iati-activity.title: Community Watershed Management
iati-activity.description: The project will contribute is to eliminate land and forest degradation in Indonesia. The objective of the project is to support effort in reducing forest and land degradation in order to restore watershed functions and ecosystem services with the outcomes being forest and land degradation reduced and watershed functions and ecosystem services restored. To achieve this objective, three outputs have been identified, which correspond with the three barriers to effective measure to reduce forest and land degradation identified above: (1) Six critical watersheds with diverse ecological and social-economic conditions demonstrate improved management using CBFWM; (2) Governmental agencies provide clear and quantifiable support to the development of CBFWM initiatives; and (3) Coordination among and between different levels of government generates consistent policies and programmes that support CBFWM.

result.title: Development plans and programmes integrate environmentally sustainable solutions in a manner that promotes poverty reduction, MDG achievement and low-emission climate-resilient development
result.description: In conclusion, until present, the Project has not done sufficient to ensure sustainability, either at the site level or at the watershed level. iati-activity.title: Strengthening Indonesia Mitigation and Adaptation
iati-activity.description: Strengthening Indonesia Mitigation and Adapttaion Strategy to Climate Change (SIMAS: CC)
iati-activity.participating-org: UNDP AS ADMINISTRATIVE AGENT FOR A JOINT PROGRAMME PASS THROUGH ARRANGEMENT

iati-activity.title: Strengthening Mitigation
iati-activity.description:
Expected CP Outcome: National institutions and other key stakeholders are coherently and effectively addressing Climate Change (CC) adaptation and mitigation and Ozone layer protection
Indonesia faces challenges in relations to rapid deforestation, peat-soil degradations and other forms of land-use change that has potential to release carbon stored in existing and converted forest areas. Indonesia must also address potential impacts of projected contributions from greenhouse gases (GHG) emissions to climate change). The rapid increase of fossil fuel consumption (over 6% per year) also contributes to climate change, and in this sense Indonesia must consider both mitigation and adaptation aspects
Considering challenges through this Project Initiation Plan (PIP), UNDP will support the government in addressing the needs and priorities of Indonesia by working closely with relevant responsible party (-ies) to develop six new proposals on (1) low emission on degraded land (biochar); (2) greenhouse gases inventory (third national communications); (3) green commodities (sustainable palm oil); (4) cross protocol cooperation on emission reduction (climate benefits in Air Conditioner and refrigeration systems); (5) climate change adaptation and risk management (Climate Risk Management or CRM); and (6) private sector climate change financing initiatives.

iati-activity.title: Support to Climate Change Trust Fund
iati-activity.description: Support to Preparation Arrangement for Indonesia Climate Change Trust Fund (ICCTF) - Full Size

iati-activity.title: Climate Change Trust Fund
iati-activity.description:
UNDAF Outcome(s) : Increased opportunities for sustainable livelihoods by 2010 improved environmental living conditions CPAP Expected Output(s) : Capacity of Government, private sector and civil society to adhere to the international environmental agreements increased.
Descriptions : The Government of Indonesia established the Indonesia Climate Change Trust Fund (ICTTF) decree in September 2009. The ICCTF shall be nationally managed, and is part of government commitment to implement the Jakarta Commitment's to enhance national ownership and improve aid coordination in response to climate change. In this framework, the Government and the UNDP shall jointly establish and implement the project titled "Preparatory Arrangements for the Indonesia Climate Change Trust Fund (PREP-ICCTF)". Under term of signed Letter of Agreement (September 2009), the objects of the project shall be to (1) Provide support to priority climate change initiatives as prioritized by the Government, during an interim period, while the ICCTF is being established; (2) Provide Support and development and establishment of the ICCTF; and (3)support capacity development needs of the Government of Indonesia for the efficient and effective implementation of the ICCTF. The project shall enable the Government and national trustee to gradually assume full operational responsibility within the 18 month interim period.
The initial USD 50,000 TRAC budget is intended for preparatory activities, before the full funding from DFID and other donors is received. The key objectives of the project shall be to (1) Provide support to priority climate change initiatives as prioritized by the Government, during an interim period, while teh ICCTF is being established; (2) provide support and development for establishment of the ICCTF; (3) support capacity development needs of teh Government of Indonesia for the efficient and effective implementation of teh ICCTF.

In this framework, the Government and the UNDP shall jointly establish and implement the project titled "Preparatory Arrangements for the Indonesia Climate Change Trust Fund (PREP-ICCTF)". Under term of signed Letter of Agreement (September 2009), the objects of the project shall be to (1) Provide support to priority climate change initiatives as prioritized by the Government, during an interim period, while the ICCTF is being established; (2) Provide Support and development and establishment of the ICCTF; and (3)support capacity development needs of the Government of Indonesia for the efficient and effective implementation of the ICCTF. The project shall enable the Government and national trustee to gradually assume full operational responsibility within the 18 month interim period.
The initial USD 50,000 TRAC budget is intended for preparatory activities, before the full funding from DFID and other donors is received. The key objectives of the project shall be to (1) Provide support to priority climate change initiatives as prioritized by the Government, during an interim period, while teh ICCTF is being established; (2) provide support and development for establishment of the ICCTF; (3) support capacity development needs of teh Government of Indonesia for the efficient and effective implementation of teh ICCTF.

iati-activity.title: MDG Strategy and Mechanisms
iati-activity.description:
Output 1: Strategy and mechanisms to implement the MDG Roadmap are developed at the national and sub-national level
Indicators: 1) Capacity development assistance framework for the MDG Roadmap (including institutional & regulatory elements) developed and implemented and number of GOI and non-GOI organizations at national and sub-national levels benefitting from the technical support, particularly in UNPDF areas 2) Existence of mechanisms and procedures for providing financial management, technical assistance and oversight to sub-national GOI and non-GOI organizations during the implementation of the MDG road-map and number of local governments and non-government organizations assisted, particularly in UNPDF areas
Baseline : 1) Partial existence of programmatic capacity development strategies, but no capacity development assistance framework strategy for implementing the MDG road map 2) Nonexistence of mechanisms and procedures for providing financial management technical assistance and oversight to sub-national governments.

iati-activity.title: Project Operation Support
iati-activity.description:
The project document was revised to reflect a change in the implementation arrangements for the "Support to the Establishment of Indonesia REDD+ Infrastructure and Capacity project" signed on 1 December 2010.
Pursuant to a decision by the President of Republic of Indonesia, and following of the formal exchange of letters between the President's Delivery Unit for Development Monitoring and Oversight (UKP4), and BAPPENAS, and UNDP, and BAPPENAS, the Implementing Partner for the REDD+ project has been changed from the "REDD+ Taskforce" to UKP4. In line with this, any and all references to the "REDD+ Taskforce" serving in the capacity of the Implementing Partnefrs in the project document signed on 1 December 2010 and amended on 19 May 2011, has now been changed to the "President's Delivery Unit for Development Monitoring and Oversight." All other substantive, programmatic, operational and implementation arrangement remain unaltered and as stated in the revised project document of 19 May 2011.
Under this revision, the budget and implementation timeframe of the project also remain as stated in the 19 May 2011 revised project document.

iati-activity.description: Tsunami Recovery Waste Management Project (TRWMP): Initiated through the Aceh Emergency Rsponse Transitional programme (ERTR).
iati-activity.participating-org: INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT ASSOCIATION ACTING AS TRUSTEE FOR THE MULTI-DONOR TRUST FUND FOR ACEH AND NORTH SUMATRA

iati-activity.title: Tsunami Recovery Waste Project
iati-activity.description:
1. District government sanitation departments' financial and technical capacity for sustainable waste management systems increased.
2. Detailed design and construction of permanent district landfills prepared, including the regional sanitary landfill in Kota Banda Aceh Aceh Besar.
3. Sustainable private sector waste management livelihoods to increase the economic benefits of recycling and decrease the volume of waste in Aceh created
4.The project is effectively and efficiently managed, monitored, evaluated, and audited.

iati-activity.title: UNREDD in Indonesia
iati-activity.description: United Nations Collaboartive Programme on Reducing Emission from Deforestation and Forese Degradation (UNREDD) in Indonesia
iati-activity.participating-org: UNDP AS ADMINISTRATIVE AGENT FOR A JOINT PROGRAMME PASS THROUGH ARRANGEMENT

iati-activity.title: Local actors capacity building
iati-activity.description: In September 2008, the Global United Nations Collaborative Programme on Reducing Emission from Deforestation and Forrest Degradations in Developing Countries (UN-REDD Programme) was launched aiming to assist tropical forest countries in establishing affair, equitable and transparent REDD regime. Indonesia is one of the main pilot countries for the initial phase. This will be funded by the government of Norway as part of Northwest International Climate and Forest Initiative which was announced during the UNFCCC conference at Bali in 2007. The proposed National Joint Programme (NJP) aims to support The Government of Indonesia (GoI) to timely develop a REDD architecture that will allow a fair, equitable and transparent REDD implementation, and a sustainable contribution of forestry to a reduction of forestry related greenhouse gas emissions. Multi stakeholder participation in REDD is of critical importance to REDD readiness. Recognizing the importance to do so, the government has been initially working through the IFCA multi stakeholder alliance. IFCA organized and streamlined stakeholders input. Amongst others, this resulted in an initial outline of what was called a REDD supply chain. Furthermore, subject matter related analysis were conducted which fat into a final consolidation report that has formed the foundation for Indonesia's National REDD Strategy. Recently, the Ministry of Forestry has issued a Ministerial Decrees no. 30/2009 and no. 36/2009, on REDD regulations. The decrees was issued after various in depth multi stakeholder consultations on REDD regulations. The multi stakeholder consultations process also includes people and local communities potentially affected by REDD, UNREDD is keenly aware of the concerned raised by local communities and civil society organization (CSOs) of an emerging REDD scheme in Indonesia. On May 2009, an in depth stakeholder consultation with the indigenous people representatives (hereafter referred to as local community representatives) and CSOs was conducted as part of the development of the UNREDD programme. Inputs from consultations had been used to refine the proposal and will guide later implementation. Provincial and district governments are developing policies and have sound interests in developing REDD as an effort to strengthen forest development in their area. While this initiative needs support, better communication between districts, province and central government is essential to make REDD successful in the longer term. Furthermore, particular attention is required to enhance capacity of local government and society in managing forest in the context of the local development planning, including supporting the establishment and capacity building of forest management units. To support the development o9f the national and international REDD architecture, the programme will also assists local governments with preparing and piloting REDD activities on the ground. The result will provide important inputs to the national discussions and decision making processes. The Objective of UNREDD Indonesia programme is "to support GoI in attaining REDD readiness". In order to secure this objective, three outcomes with subsequent outputs and activities will be pursued: Outcome 1: Strengthened Multistakeholder participations and consensus at national level Output 1.1 (UNDP): Consensus on key issues for national REDD policy development Output 1.2 (UNDP): REDD lesson learned Output 1.3 (UNEP): Communications programme Outcome 2: Successful demonstration of establishing of a REL, MRV and fair payment systems best on the national REDD architecture. Output 2.1 (FAO): Improved capacity and methodology design for forest carbon inventory within a Measurement, Reporting and Verification system (MRV), including sub-national pilot implementation. Output 2.2 (FAO): Reference Emissions Level (REL) Output 2.3 (UNDP): Harmonized fair and equitable payment mechanism at provincial level Output 2.4 (UNEP): Toolkit for priority setting towards maximizing potential carbon benefits and incorporating co-benefits, such as bio-diversity conservation and poverty alleviations under MDG. Outcome 3: Capacity established to implement REDD at decentralized levels Output 3.1 (UNDP): Capacity for spatial sosio-economic planning incorporating REDD at the district level Output 3.2 (UNDP): Empowered local stakeholders are able to benefit from REDD Output 3.3 (UNDP): Multi stakeholders endorsed district plans for REDD implementation
